data.text: How to Charge E-bikes when Cycle Touring?
Is it possible to tour with an e bike? Is there any other way of charging other than a wall socket? TIA.
Solar panels and charge boost converter to direct charge or extra battery
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: just curious is the solar panel really a practical solution. I have 2 batteries one a 48v 14amp the other a 36v 7amp (different bikes). It takes the former 6 hours to change, the latter 4. Agree ref 2 batteries.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: yes it is you can make a trailer for the panel and extra battery panel will also keep your gear dry from the top you can even do multiple panels or slide/fold out panels and a charge boost converter is so you can charge your main battery during riding or a extra battery so youre slowly topping them off or if used on the main one will couse the battery to be less drained at the end with a proper build you can get about 450km of range out of 2 sets of big batterys and a proper trailer with fold out panels you take a break when the sun is highest fold out the panels and you can charge better

It‚Äôs a fantastic alternative, but you do need mains power. Some people have knocked up solar-powered chargers on trailers, etc. but charging is slow and unpredictable. I have used a second battery in my pannier as a backup, which lets me do two days before charging.

data.author: Elizabeth Burgess

data.text: well, really simple - but I'll explain anyway. Speed restriction An unassisted bike can ride as fast as they want, speed restrictions on road signs do not apply. This comes from reasoning that most people travel between 18 and 25 km/h (generally only road racing bikes exceed those speeds, and they ride on roads instead of bike paths anyway). Mofas/snorfietsen are restricted to 25 km/h as well, allowing them to ride on bike paths as well. With those logics in mind, the speed restriction for pedal assisted bikes (not s-pedelecs, not e-bikes) was set to 25 km/h (with tolerance up to 27 km/h). De-restriction There are three classes: - pedal assisted bikes up to 25 km/h. - pedal assisted bikes (so-called s-pedelecs) up to 40 km/h (which then need a license plate, insurance, mandatory helmet, are allowed on streets only, no bike lanes) - e bikes that need no assistance, same laws as s-pedelec. If you de-restrict a pedelec, it becomes a s-pedelec. As you will have no license plate nor insurance (nor be able to obtain these as the bike is not categorized as such), you will get pulled from traffic (or bike path ulif you're even more stupid), get heavily fined and if you're really running out of luck, the bike will be shredded. On an even more extreme note, if you would cause an accident with material damage or bodily harm/death, your normal liability insurance will pay for the damage but will get those costs back from you. And you will know, why you are going to work for. No job, no problem. Someone will be assigned to manage your welfare money, paying all the bills and giving you only a sort of allowance money. There is no winning in this situation, which is good.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: You said..."you" then allow pedal assisted bikes to go too fast.'... so gain, how does someone 'allow' others to go to fast or more to the point, how do i allow others to go to fast? Waffling on about the difference between an ebike and pedal assist has nothing to do with it. Most people view them as being one and the same plus no one 'allows' others to go to fast.

data.text: The 'you' is actually your government, passing appropriate laws. Your bike shop collective selling appropriate electrified bicycles, your local trading standards official not imposing seizure and forfeit on unregulated sales of 'unlawful' bicycles. In the UK is is mandatory for a road going bicycle to have two working brakes, a track bike only has one (the fixed gear) so must be clearly marked as 'not for road use'. When someone does use it on the road and is involved in a road raffic incident then the gates of hell are opened and the rabble are roused.

Some people think that there‚Äôs no demand.
data.author: Dar Lane

data.text: As a cyclist and an engineer I must comment on those suggesting a dynamo hub. This won't work! 1st from an energy budget, you drive the dynamo with the bike which is driven by the battery and you. There's no gain. This is the equivalent of lifting yourself up into the air by your pulling on your shoelaces. 2nd even if you didn't drive the bike by battery at the amount of energy created by the dynamo is so small ( 5 watts) and in most cases is too low a voltage to be used as a charging source ( to charge a battery the charge voltage must greater than the battery voltage). A solar panel is least a start in right direction as at least the charging energy is coming from outside the system, though once again a very small amount relatively speaking.... charge all day ride an hour or two at night? Just do as others suggested plan your route with charging locations in mind.
data.author: Robert Wyland

data.text: , thank you for putting it succinctly. I‚Äôm a touring cyclist but not an engineerÔøº and I wasn‚Äôt sure if I could express that same idea without sounding condescending. Ôøº
data.author: Louie Garcia

data.text: I think they're suggesting using solar panels at night and riding during the day! The first law of thermodynamics isn't applicable in Facebookland, but the second law is. There are many high-entropy neural networks at large.
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: I disagree, junctions are often at the bottom of a hill, so you use pedals and battery to get to the top of a hill, then as you come down the other side you have to brake, if instead of turning this energy into heating up the brake disc you could put the energy back into the battery (auto switching at above assist speed) this would improve range (although I accept perpetual motion is not possible)
data.author: Simon Jap McClelland

data.text: , while you have a point, I would say the additional energy recovered is small and also difficult to use in charging the main bike battery. Going down the hill you will not recover all the energy available, probably much less than 50% probably closer to 5-10% at best. My bet is you will still be braking to stop, and the dynamo hubs are not 100% efficient by a long shot. Their output efficiency depends on speed and above a certain speed falls off as they are optimized to create energy at lower speeds. Will the dynamo create energy while going down hill? Yes, but not as much as you would like. Most dynamo hubs create either 3 or 6 volts and about 3 watts to use with lights. ( your ebike uses 100+ watts for a longer period than it takes for you to descend) Most e-bike batteries are 36 volts or higher. So now you must use an upvoltage dc to dc converter which also had inefficiencies. So your plan is to take 3 watts over a short period to offset use of 100 watts over a long period ( a time ratio of climb to descend might be 4:1) Would it help? Yes. However without significant input. From a practical stand point you will have to add some circuitry ( how's you electrical design ability?) For very minimal gain. If you could design a energy braking system that tapped into what your talking about you could see some efficiency gains ( dynamo hubs are not designed as brakes but for lights) Superpedestrian made a ebike conversion wheel that was designed for just that. Back Pedal their wheel and it went into regenerative braking mode. They saw at most a 10% gain in range ( optimistic claims I'd bet). So I still believe this not fundamentally a good idea or really readily available on the market ( for good reason). Oddly I run a dynamo hub on my ebike. But just to run lights, and the hub was there before I converted to an ebike. If you still don't believe I challenge you to try and you will find out why no one is doing this....
data.author: Robert Wyland

data.text: It's not really practicable. Electric braking requires the brakes to be effectively dynamos/alternators. The weight, complexity and expense for a very minimal gain in retrieved energy isn't worth the effort. I suspect the heat losses would be huge as well under heavy braking. The first law of thermodynamics is often the killer of some very good (on paper) ideas. And entropy (aka the second law of thermodynamics) is a gigantic pain in the neck. And they both apply here.
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: dynamo hubs are for lights AC output 6v-3w, there are devices to convert to 5v USB standard '' The initial USB 1 and 2.0 specifications described two types of power sources (5V 500mA and 5V 100mA, respectively) all too tiny for a recharge of a big motor battery , but OK topping up your phone while it is Off.

data.text: Several European countries (Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, Austria) have countless charging stations. And most are for free as well. You can use them with a supercharger cable as well, so you don't have to bring your charger perse (just have to plan your routes and stays accordingly).
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: Lithium titanate pack will charge in full in 20 minutes. This will cost about $3000 last time I looked. You'll have to source your own cells, build your own and tow it in a trailer. Other than that, carry two to three normal lithium ebike batteries and chargers and switch them out every couple hours of riding. Then when you charge you charge them all at once, resulting in an effective charge rate that is 3x the normal charge rate. So they will charge to full from their 30 percent depleted state about 2-3hrs.
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text: Your final option is towing a solar pv trailer with an mppt charger to harvest energy throughout the day

data.text: This is my e-bike setup. 160watt solar panel mounted on a trailer. The panel is motorised so it tracks the sun on a X-Y axis. I have a battery in the trailer and one on the bike. I use a MPPT boost charge controller that converts the solar panel voltage of 18 volts to 54 volts to charge the battery on the bike. The battery in the trailer I use to charge things like a camera, phone, drones and suchlike. On a good sunny day here in Europe after a 100km ride, I have used about 10% of the battery power. If I find a good sunny spot late afternoon/early evening I can top the battery up while having a rest and eating.
data.author: Gary Hall

data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text:
I'm 70 and have dodgy knees as well. I'd still recommend not using an e-bike. But maybe that's just me. I'm very much of a minimalist. It's the (i) initial cost, (ii) limited range, (iii) excess weight and (iv) added complication that colours my thinking. I bought a pedal assist (i.e uk legal) ebike some years ago for going to and from work; 11 miles each way. I had to charge the battery at both ends of the journey to be sure of getting home under power. It's a great bike, but it's a pig to ride without electric assistance. I wouldn't want to tour on an e-bike for 2 reasons: 1 - you are limited by the battery capacity. 2 - riding an e-bike without power is grossly inefficient. Yes, I know that anybody can tour on anything. But why spend mega-bucks to make life limited and difficult? I've just found this blog. It's probably going to be more useful to you that anything a re-offending old grumpy like me can say. As they say, "a gramme of experience outweighs a tonne of theory." https://ebikecycletourists.com/ They also have a facebook page:
E-Bike Cycle Tourists | We set a new world ebike long distance record in Europe and the UK
ebikecycletourists.com
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: I think the key comment here is "bought some years ago". Things have moved on my Ribble weighs 14kg, I have had up to 120km out it with 40 percent battery left. I have just cycled 900km plus around Holland and Germany with the motor switch off for 800km plus (so flat). So not that heavy, good range, easy to ride, but yes comes at a price but worth every penny if u are getting on or have health problems (me). I ride with lots of people in their 70s and 80s who have lifetimes spent on bikes and I have lost count of how many have bought the same bike as mine after seeing it. Like a lot of people you are not seeing the full picture in respect of E Bikes and that's the problem, too many people condemn them through lack of knowledge, misunderstanding, arrogance or vanity (the bain of the cycling world). I note you are in the UK, if you still cycle but are starting to struggle a bit have a look at the Ribble website, best regards.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: Haha. Thank you, but I'll continue to struggle and I'll be building my own bio-bikes, thanks. Yes, the Ribbles look nice, but none of them appeals to me. I hope you're not accusing me of condemning things "through lack of knowledge, misunderstanding, arrogance or vanity (the bain of the cycling world)." If you actually read my post, you'd find that (i) I was speaking from experience (albeit out-of-date), (ii) I readily embrace that others' viewpoints are equally valid and (iii) I pointed the op in the direction of a very useful and well-constructed website diametrically opposed to my own personal views. I also admit to being an old grump ... but not lacking knowledge nor possessing a majority of negative personal attributes.
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: I wasn't riding my bike anymore because I hated pushing it up the steep hills. I don't have to get off and push my ebike so I'm getting more exercise than with a regular bike that I didn't have fun riding.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: Good for you. I'm not dissing e-bikes in any way. I'm the proud owner of one that I used for the 22-mile round trip to work. I'd already retired and sold my car and then returned to work. I wasn't about to buy another car and it was just too much for my creaky knees on any of my push bikes up hill and down dale. It was brilliant. Now I've retired again (!), Mrs occasionally uses it for getting to work. (She's younger than me by quite a few years ... don't really know how I managed to get her!) No. It's all about enjoying your bikes. Now I'm retired and can choose where and when to ride, I prefer a bio-bike, but e-bikes are great!
data.author: Michael Papworth

data.text: I have a friend who did the Transamerica by eBike. I suspect he rode the charge dead and recharged in an outlet, but I'll ask him. Like has been said below, dynamo's won't work, there isn't enough charge. Think about that, the whole hybrid car useses dynamo's to add a little bit of charge back to the system, but never enough to offset the need for either gasoline or a power charger. Some of the cars have dynamos on all four wheels, at worst two. I'm sure you could do it with solar, but you'd need a huge panel or a lot of sunny time charging. Of course that is the best time to be riding.

data.author: Andy McMahon

data.text: The few people I know of who tour in the west, where there are long distances between services, carefully plan out their route and take along one or two extra batteries. That adds extra weight, not to mention the expense, but it gets them to civilization.
data.author: Benjamin Tud

data.text: Just tow a trailer with a generator on it. üòâ
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: The bigger the battery you can use the further you can go. It's not hard to plan a trip with overnight stops to suit your battery power. High cadence, low gear, low power setting takes you further. Extra weight, panniers clothes camping gear all reduces your distance too, so some compromises are needed on distance, plus of course terrain - flat vs hilly.
data.author: Hugh Wilson
